subject: Physical Fitness
title: Tendinopathy Explained
description: A quick, practical guide to Tendinopathy Explained.

hook.text: Tendinitis means inflammation. But most chronic tendon pain has no inflammation at all. The name is misleading.

buildup.text: Tendinopathy is the correct term. It describes tendon pain with structural changes in the collagen matrix.

discovery.text: The tendon's collagen becomes disorganized, like tangled ropes instead of neat parallel fibers.

twist.text: Anti-inflammatory drugs don't help tendinopathy because there's no inflammation to fight. They may even delay healing.

climax.text: Progressive loading â€” gradually increasing stress on the tendon â€” is the most effective treatment available.

punchline.text: Tendon pain isn't inflammation. Load it progressively and it reorganizes.

quiz.question: Why are anti-inflammatory drugs often ineffective for chronic tendon pain?
options: Because most chronic tendon pain involves structural changes, not inflammation
Because tendons don't respond to any medication
Because the drugs are too weak
